list.title: Question 1
list.content:
For a fixed mass of gas at a constant temperature, what happens to the volume if the pressure of the gas is doubled?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Volume will remain the same
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Volume will double
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Volume will be halved
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Volume will increase exponentially
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
One of the laws of gases states that, for a fixed amount of gas held at a constant temperature, the volume of a gas is inversely proportional to its pressure.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Which of the following conditions makes gases deviate from ideal behavior?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ High pressure and high temperature
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Low pressure and low temperature
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ High pressure and low temperature
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Low pressure and high temperature
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At high pressures and very low temperatures, the inter-particle forces strengthen, spaces between particles decrease causing the deviation from ideal gas behaviour $\dfrac{PV}{nRT}$ > 1.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Based on the graph below, choose the correct statement that describes the relationship between pressure and temperature for a fixed mass and volume of a gas?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5b7d708-dada-487b-9f1b-ee2fb3f45b47/images/02187be4-3809-445d-b70e-4ae6dde3de0d/1.3-36.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is inversely proportional to the absolute temperature
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is directly proportional to the square of the absolute temperature
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is inversely proportional to the square of the absolute temperature
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Pressure is directly proportional to the absolute temperature
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The graph of P vs T shows a linear graph (straight line passing through the origin) that rises upward. This graph shows that P is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. As the absolute temperature increases, the pressure of the gas also increases.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: The ideal gas equation is a formula that combines the relationship between pressure, volume, temperature, and the number of moles. - Complete the table below by calculating the missing variables of the ideal gas equation. [4] $\mathbf{P} $$\mathbf{V}$$\mathbf{n}$$\mathbf{T}$(1)$\quad 0.015\,\textrm{m}^{3}\quad$$0.400\,\textrm{mol}$$37\,{}^\circ \mathrm{C}$$\quad 152,000\,\textrm{Pa}\quad$(2)$2.00\,\textrm{mol}$$\quad 298\,\textrm{K}\quad$$31,000\,\textrm{Pa}$$0.25\,\textrm{m}^{3}$(3)$271\,\textrm{K}$$250\,\textrm{kPa}$$0.75\,\textrm{dm}^{3}$$\quad 0.580\,\textrm{mol}\quad$(4) - A $256\,\textrm{cm}^{3}$ flask contains $0.800\,\textrm{g}$ of a gaseous compound with an empirical formula of CHCl. The pressure and the temperature of the gas are respectively $1.00\times 10^{5}\,\textrm{Pa}$ and $373\,\textrm{K}$. Determine the molecular formula of the compound. [4]
list.markScheme:
- For (1): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate the pressure of the gas.
  $\begin{aligned}
  PV &= nRT \\[3pt]
  P &= \dfrac{nRT}{V} \\
  P &= \dfrac{(0.400\,\text{mol})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(310\,\text{K})}{0.015\,\text{m}^{3}} = \answer{6.9\times 10^{4}\,\text{Pa}}\,  \checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Temperature must be given in Kelvin.
  $T(\text{K}) = 37 + 273 = 310\,\text{K}$
  For (2): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate for the volume of the gas:
  $\begin{aligned}
  PV &= nRT \\
  V &= \dfrac{nRT}{P} \\
  V &= \dfrac{(2.00\,\text{mol})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(298\,\text{K})}{152000\,\text{Pa}} = \answer{0.0326\,\textrm{m}^{3}}\, \checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  For (3): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate for the number of moles of the gas.
  $\begin{aligned}
  PV &= nRT \\
  n &= \dfrac{PV}{RT} \\
  n &= \dfrac{(31000\,\text{Pa})(0.25\,\text{m}^{3})}{(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(271\,\text{K})} = \answer{3.4\,\textrm{mol}}\, \checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  For (4): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate the temperature of the gas. Make sure that pressure is in Pascals and volume is in m$^{3}$.
  $\begin{aligned}
  PV &= nRT \\
  T &= \dfrac{PV}{nR} \\
  T &= \dfrac{(250000\,\text{Pa})(0.00075\,\text{m}^{3})}{(0.580\,\text{mol})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})} = \answer{39\,\text{K}}\, \checkmark
  \end{aligned}$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Volume must be given in m$^3$.
  $V = (0.75\,\text{dm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\,\text{m}^3}{1000\,\text{dm}^3}\right) = 0.00075\,\text{m}^3$
- $M_{gas} = \dfrac{(0.800\,\text{g})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(373\,\text{K})}{(1.00\times 10^{5}\,\text{Pa})(256\times 10^{-6}\,\text{m}^{3})} = \answer{96.9\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}\, \checkmark$
  $M_{\ce{CHCl}} = 12.01 + 1.01 + 35.45 = \answer{48.47\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}\, \checkmark$
  $\dfrac{96.9\textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}}{48.47\textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}}$ â‰ˆ 2 $\checkmark$
  The molecular formula is $\ce{C2H2Cl2}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Step 1: Use the ideal gas equation to calculate the molar mass of the gas: $PV = nRT = \left(\dfrac{m}{M}\right)RT$
  Therefore, $M = \dfrac{mRT}{PV}$
  Step 2: Calculate the empirical formula molar mass.
  Step 3: Determine the molecular formula.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
A sample of gas at the top of a mountain has a pressure of $75\text{ kPa}$ and a volume of $4.0\text{ dm}^3.$ If that same sample is brought to the bottom of the mountain where the pressure is now $100\text{ kPa},$ what is the new volume of the gas assuming that the temperature is kept constant?


- A. $\hspace{1em}0.75\text{ dm}^3$
- B. $\hspace{1em}0.19\text{ dm}^3$
- C. $\hspace{1em}3.0\text{ dm}^3$
- D. $\hspace{1em}5.3\text{ dm}^3$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
This question is answered using the Ideal Gas Law equation, $PV = nRT.$ It is assumed that the moles of the gas are the same and the temperature remains constant, so we can set $PV$ for each scenario to be equal to each other:
$P_1V_1 = P_2V_2$
where

- $P_1V_1$ is  the pressure and volume at the top of the mountain
- $P_2V_2$ isthe pressure and volume at the bottom of the mountain

Rearranging,
$V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{P_2} = \dfrac{(75\text{ kPa})(4.0\text{ dm}^3)}{100\text{ kPa}} = \answer{3.0\text{ dm}^{3}}$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Avogadro's law describes the relationship between the volume of gases and the number of moles measured at the same pressure and temperature. - Draw a graph that shows the variation of $V$ as $n$ changes. [1] - A sample of nitrogen gas contains $1.78\,\text{mol}$ and occupies a volume of $2.60\,\text{dm}^{3}$ at room temperature. Determine the number of moles of the $\ce{N2}$ gas if it occupies a volume of $3.50\,\text{dm}^{3}$. [1] - $15.0\,\text{g}$ of $\ce{O2}$ gas occupies a volume of $6.20\,\text{dm}^{3}$. Calculate the volume occupied by $30.0\,\text{g}$ of $\ce{O2}$ at the same temperature and pressure. [2] - Calculate the volume occupied by $50.0\,\text{g}$ of $\ce{CO2}$ at STP. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The graph shows a straight line passing through the origin. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $V$ and $n$ are directly proportional.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ecced072-860f-443c-8954-e8c5edc84891/images/f0f74ac4-eaab-41d5-a618-aa4ae93b3e3e/1.3-40a.png)



- $n_2 = \dfrac{(3.50\,\text{dm}^3)(1.78\,\text{mol})}{(2.60\,\text{dm}^3)} =$ $2.40\,\text{mol}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  Use the Avogadro's law equation $\dfrac{V_1}{n_1} = \dfrac{V_2}{n_2}$
  Derive the formula for $n_2$:
  $n_2 = \dfrac{(V_2)(n_1)}{V_1}$
- $n_1 = \dfrac{15.0\,\text{g}}{32.0\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} =$ $0.469\,\text{mol}$
  $n_2 = \dfrac{30.0\,\text{g}}{32.0\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} =$ $0.938\,\text{mol}$ $\checkmark$
  $V_2 = \dfrac{(V_1)(n_2)}{n_1}$
  $V_2 = \dfrac{(6.20\,\text{dm}^{3})(0.938\,\text{mol})}{(0.469\,\text{mol})} =$ $12.4\text{dm}^3$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $M(\ce{O2}) = (16.0)(2) = 32.0\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}$
  Step 1: Calculate the number of moles; $n = \dfrac{m}{M}$
  Step 2: Derive the formula for $V_2$ using Avogadro's law equation.
- n$_{\ce{CO2}} = \dfrac{50.0\,\text{g}}{44.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} =$ $1.14\,\text{mol}$ $\checkmark$
  At STP, $V = n\times V_m = (1.14\,\text{mol})(22.7\,\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) =$ $25.9\,\text{dm}^{3}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  $M(\ce{CO2}) = 12.01 + (16.00)(2) = 44.01\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}$
  Step 1: Calculate the number of moles of $\ce{CO2}$; $n = \dfrac{m}{M}$
  Step 2: At STP, $V = n\times \textrm{molar volume}$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Based on the table below, what is the correct calculation to determine the final volume of a fixed mass of gas:

InitialFinalPressure (atm)1.001.60Temperature ($^\circ$C)2010Volume (dm$^3$)5.00?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{(1.00 \ \textrm{atm})(5.00 \  \textrm{dm}^3)(283 \ \textrm{K})}{(1.60\ \textrm{atm})(293\ \textrm{K})}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00 \ \textrm{dm}^3)(10 \ ^\circ\mathrm{C})}{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(20 \  ^\circ\mathrm{C})}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00\ \textrm{dm}^3)(20 ^\circ\mathrm{C})}{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(10 ^\circ\mathrm{C})}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00\ \textrm{dm}^3)(283\textrm{\ K})}{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(293\textrm{\ K})}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Ideal gas equation: $PV= nRT$
The number of moles is the same since there is a fixed mass of gas, and R is a constant.
$P_1V_1= nRT_1$  and $P_2V_2 = nRT_2$
The temperature must be measured on the absolute scale, in K.
Using the combined gas law equation,
$\dfrac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \dfrac{P_2V_2}{T_2}$
we can derive the expression:
$V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1T_2}{P_2T_1} = \dfrac{(1.00\,\text{atm})(5.00\,\text{dm}^3)(283\,\text{K})}{(1.60\,\text{atm})(293\,\text{K})}$
$10\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = 283\,\text{K}$
$20\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = 293\,\text{K}$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Under which conditions would a gas deviate the most from the ideal gas model?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$1 atm, 298 K
- B.$\hspace{1em}$200 atm, 25 $^\circ$C
- C.$\hspace{1em}$200 kPa, 25 $^\circ$C
- D.$\hspace{1em}$100 kPa, 298 K
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\text{Explanation:}}$
The student must understand that gases deviate from an ideal gas when the temperature is low and when the pressure is high.

- At low temperatures, the particles move slower and thus are able to form more intermolecular forces.
- At high pressure the particles are closer together, also allowing for more plentiful attractive forces.

In both of these cases, intermolecular forces of attraction cannot be assumed to be negligible and so the gas under those conditions is no longer considered an ideal gas.
This question is categorized as medium because the student needs to carefully consider the answer choices. A pressure of 1 atm is the same as 100 kPa. Likewise, 298 K is the same as 25 $^\circ$C. A pressure of 200 kPa, while higher, is not high enough to drastically increase attractive forces. A pressure of 200 atm would be consistent with the pressure in a compressed gas cylinder when the gas is in liquid form, and is therefore not behaving as an ideal gas.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
A sample of oxygen gas with volume $V_1$ is at pressure $1.00\times\ 10^5\,\text{Pa}$. At constant temperature, what is the pressure if $V_1$ is halved?


- A.$\hspace{1em}2.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}$
- B.$\hspace{1em}5.00\times 10^4\,\text{Pa}$
- C.$\hspace{1em}5.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}$
- D.$\hspace{1em}2.00\times 10^4\,\text{Pa}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to Boyle's Law, at constant temperature:
$P_1V_1 = P_2V_2$
Rearranging,
$P_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{V_2} = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{\frac{1}{2}V_1} = 2P_1$$P_2 = \answer{2.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}}$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
$14.01\,\text{g}$ of nitrogen gas ($\ce{N2}$) is reacted with excess $\ce{H2}$. What volume of ammonia ($\ce{NH3}$) gas would be produced at STP? The molar volume of a gas at STP is $22.7\,\text{dm}^3$.
$\ce{N2(g) + 3H2(g) -> 2NH3(g)}$


- A.$\hspace{1em} 11.4\,\text{dm}^3$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\,22.7\,\text{dm}^3$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\,34.1\,\text{dm}^3$
- D.$\hspace{1em}\,45.4\,\text{dm}^3$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Calculate the number of moles of ammonia gas ($\ce{NH3}$) that will be produced from $14.01\,\text{g}$ of nitrogen gas $\ce{N2}$.
$n_\ce{N2} = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{14.01\,\text{g}}{28.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 0.5\,\text{mol}$$n_{\ce{NH3}} = 2\,n_{\ce{N2}} = 2 \times 0.5 = 1.0\,\text{mol}$
Calculate the volume of ammonia gas produced at STP.
$V = n  V_m = 1.0\,\text{mol} \times 22.7\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} = \answer{22.7\,\text{dm}^3}$
$\ $

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
6.00 g of ethane gas $(M_r \approx 30)$ is placed in a flexible container at STP. The conditions are then changed to a new pressure of 200,000 Pa and a new temperature of 546 K.
What is the new volume of the container after equilibrating to the new temperature and pressure?
The molar volume of a gas at STP is 22.7 dm$^3$.


- A.$\hspace{1em}22.7\,\text{dm}^3$
- B.$\hspace{1em}2.27\,\text{dm}^3$
- C.$\hspace{1em}4.54\,\text{dm}^3$
- D.$\hspace{1em}9.08\,\text{dm}^3$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
At STP, standard temperature and pressure, the pressure is 100 kPa (100,000 Pa) and the temperature is 0 $^\circ$C (273 K). A sample of ethane gas is taken from standard conditions and put into new conditions where the pressure is doubled (200000 kPa) and the temperature is doubled (546 K).
The amount of ethane is constant through the experiment:
$n_\ce{C2H6} = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{6.00\,\text{g}}{30\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.200\,\text{mol}$
Using the molar volume of a gas at STP, we can deduce the original volume of the gas:
$V_1 = n V_m = 0.200\,\text{mol}\times 22.7\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} = 4.54\,\text{dm}^3$
The final volume of the gas can be determined from the combined gas law:
$\dfrac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \dfrac{P_2V_2}{T_2}$
Solving for $V_2$:
$V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1T_2}{T_1P_2}$;
Logically, the pressure $P_2$ and the temperature $T_2$ doubled, so the volume $V_2$ remains the same. Mathematically,
$V_2 = \dfrac{100000\,\text{Pa}\times 4.54\,\text{dm}^3\times 546\,\text{K}}{273\,\text{K}\times 200000\text{Pa}}$
The final volume of ethane is 4.54 dm$^3$.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
A $500\,\text{cm}^3$ flask is weighed empty.  After a chemical reaction was conducted, a gas was collected at SATP conditions.  The flask was found to increase in mass by $1.43\,\text{g}.$ What is the name of the gas collected?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$Hydrogen
- B.$\hspace{1em}$Oxygen
- C.$\hspace{1em}$Carbon dioxide
- D.$\hspace{1em}$Chlorine
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At SATP conditions $(P = 100 \textrm{\ kPa}, T = 298.15 \textrm{\ K})$, the ideal gas law can be used to deduce the molar mass of the unknown gas. Starting from $PV=nRT,$ and substituting $n = \frac{m}{M},$ we obtain
$PV = \dfrac{mRT}{M}$
which rearranges to
$M = \dfrac{mRT}{PV}$
Converting the volume to $\textrm{dm}^3$ (because $1 \textrm{\ J} = 1 \textrm{\ kPa dm}^3),$ and substituting the given values
$M = \dfrac{1.43 \textrm{\ g} \times 8.31 \textrm{\ J mol}^{-1} \times 298.15 \textrm{\ K}}{\textrm{\ 100 \textrm kPa} \times {0.500 \textrm{\ dm}^3}} = 70.9 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}$
Comparing this value with the molar masses of the candidate gases we can identify the unknown: hydrogen $(\ce{H2}, \ 2.02 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),$ oxygen $(\ce{O2},\ 32.00 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),$ carbon dioxide $(\ce{CO2},\ 44.01 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),$ and chlorine $(\ce{Cl2},\ 70.90 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}).$ The measured value corresponds to chlorine.
This is a challenging question because it requires students to combine experimental data with the ideal gas equation to infer an unknown identity, rather than relying on a direct recall of facts.

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Which of the following gases most closely aligns with the behavior of an ideal gas?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{Br2}$, bromine
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{H2}$, hydrogen
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{Cl2}$, chlorine
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{O2}$, oxygen
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\text{Explanation:}}$
The student must understand the concepts behind an ideal gas which assumes negligent volume and insignificant attractive forces between atoms or molecules.
As the molar mass of a chemical species increases, the attractive forces between particles also increase. This causes a deviation from the ideal gas model as the relative molecular mass increases.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty because the student must apply logic to the definition of an ideal gas.

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Which statement(s) is (are) correct about real gases?


- I.$\hspace{1.em}$Gas particles are considered to have negligible volume.
- II.$\hspace{0.7em}$At low temperatures, intermolecular forces exist.
- III.$\hspace{0.4em}$At high pressure, real gases behave as ideal gases.



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Ideal gases are described as moving particles with no volume and no intermolecular forces. In contrast, real gases take into account the small volume of particles and the intermolecular forces that can cause a deviation from the ideal behavior.
Statement I is incorrect as it applies to ideal gases only.
Real gases behave like ideal gases at high temperatures and low pressures. Statement III is incorrect.
At low temperatures, condensed phases exist, and intermolecular forces are significant. Statement II is correct.
This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must thoroughly compare and distinguish ideal and real gases.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
For a fixed amount and pressure of a gas, the volume of a reaction vessel is increased from $100 \textrm{\ m}^3$ to $200 \textrm{\ m}^3.$ The initial temperature was set at 27 $^\circ\textrm{C}.$
Which of the following rows is correct?


- Final Temperature $\newline$($\mathbf{^\circ{}C)}$Kinetic EnergyA.$\textcolor{white}{-}54$More molecules have energy greater than $\newline$ or equal to the activation energy.B.$\textcolor{white}{-}54$The same number of molecules have energy greater than  $\newline$ or equal to the activation energy.C.$-127$Fewer molecules have energy greater than  $\newline$ or equal to the activation energy.D.$\textcolor{white}{-}327$More molecules have energy greater than $\newline$ or equal to the activation energy.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For a fixed amount and pressure of gas, $n$ and $P$ are constant. Volume and temperature (in K) are directly proportional (Charles's Law).
$\dfrac{V_1}{T_1}=\ \dfrac{V_2}{T_2}$
In this case, T = 27 $^\circ$C = 300 K so,
$\dfrac{100 \textrm{ m}^3}{300 \textrm{\ K}}\ =\ \dfrac{200 \textrm{\ m}^3}{T_2} \ ; \ \ \ \ T_2 = 600 \textrm{\ K}$
In Celsius, $T_2 = 600 - 273 = \answer{327\,{}^\circ\textrm{C}}$
As temperature increases, the average kinetic energy of the systems increases and more molecules have an energy higher than the activation energy.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
A sample of gas at a certain temperature, pressure, and volume ($T_1$, $P_1$, and $V_1$) undergoes a change in temperature and pressure ($T_2$ and $P_2$). What is the new volume ($V_2$)?


- 
  
  - Before: $T_1, P_1, V_1$
  - After:	$P_2 = 2P_1 \quad \textrm{AND} \quad T_2 = \frac{1}{2} T_1$




- A.$\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{2} V_1$
- B.$\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{8} V_1$
- C.$\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{4} V_1$
- D.$\hspace{1em}4V_1$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Use the combined gas law:
$\dfrac{P_1 V_1}{T_1}= \dfrac{P_2 V_2}{T_2}$$V_2 =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 T_2}{T_1 P_2} =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 \ \frac{1}{2}T_1}{T_1\ 2P_1} =\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}V_1}{2} =$ $\frac{1}{4} V_1$
Alternate Method:
To answer this question, the student must understand and apply the relationships between temperature, pressure, and volume in the ideal gas model:
$PV = nRT$
Therefore, $V \propto T$ and $P \propto \dfrac{1}{V}$.
Since volume and temperature are directly proportional, an increase in one will result in an increase in the other at the same magnitude.
In this case, $T_2 = \frac{1}{2}  T_1$ resulting in $V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1$.
Pressure is doubled, but since volume and pressure are inversely proportional, this results in $V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1$.
Compounding these effects results in $V_2 = \frac{1}{4} V_1$.
This question is categorized as medium because it requires an understanding of the ideal gas law and proportionalities based on $PV = nRT$.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Which graph depicts the behavior of a fixed amount of an ideal gas at constant temperature?


- A.$\hspace{0em}$B.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/9586b562-a724-4700-8648-f80b6cc09ee9/CH1226a.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/85d6b7c7-0a9a-438d-91b4-42e6561c0767/CH1226b.png)

C.D.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/2c47e38d-63db-449a-9d59-ae78aa73e245/CH12261c.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/ef61e732-30a3-4a19-938e-e398139c55e0/CH1226d.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
At constant temperature, an ideal gas obeys Boyle's law, so the product  $PV = \textrm{constant}.$ When $V$ is plotted against
$P,$ the curve must therefore be a  hyperbola because volume decreases inversely as pressure increases. If instead $\frac{1}{V}$ is plotted against $P,$ the two quantities are directly proportional and produce a straight line through the origin. Finally, a plot of $PV$ vs. $P$ should be a horizontal line, since
$PV$ does not change with pressure for an ideal gas at fixed temperature.
For ideal gases:
